title: Wednesday, 9th January 2019
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas good morning everyone
11:07 am

Manxish Morning each

Markets Live, FT Alphaville's thingmy, for another hour or so of whatever. Though sometimes, I feel the universe has accelerated beyond my ability to summarise it in realtime.

Greggs PLC (GRG:LSE): Last: 1,469, up 102 (+7.46%), High: 1,480, Low: 1,401, Volume: 356.27k
FATDAZ Morning all
Phil Greggs PR team doing sterling work this past week or two.

In terms of the actual figures, Q4's good. LFL growth +5.1% and total sales +7.2%

BE11:16am

Concerns about estate cannibalisation and cost inflation seem to be quelled for the moment.

red ted baker not so sure. says margins lower although sales were higher. think its more a relief rally after ceo troubles lowered shares
11:16 am
BE11:17am

FY18 underlying profit before tax is now expected to be at least £88m vs at least £86m in the November upgrade

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Morning.
BE11:18am

The idea here is likely that Greggs is taking share from the weak underbelly of independents, as high street footfall isn't improving any.

DJ Morning, any comment on Spectris re: https://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-6523403/Market-jitters-lead-plunge-deals-Fears-Brexit-kill-Citys-3-5bn-Spectris-takeover.html
A. M. Hullo all.Any more DNO/FP stuff?
FATDAZ re Greggs / vegans great publicity for the baker but there are apparently just 540,000 vegans in the UK less than 1% of the population I would imagine there are bigger demographics who never eat vegetables at all and are more closely aligned to Greggs core offerings so why not target them instead?
BE11:18am

Barclays incoming.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

This is a very strong Q4 trading update, even before the launch of the popular vegan sausage roll (please call for our own proprietary view after a visit to the Victoria Coach station site). LFLs in Q4 were +5.2%. When the company last updated the market, LFLs were 4.5% for the 8 weeks to 24 November, implying an improvement to 6.3% in the most recent 5 weeks. Net store openings in the year was 99 (149 new shops, 50 closures) vs previous guidance of “around 100”. What has driven this performance seems varied. We have observed that the company has a tendency to go on “tears” in trading depending on range, much more so than our pub or restaurant coverage stocks. Hot drinks and breakfasts are flagged in the statement, as well as seasonal ranges, but also investment in staff training and systems. A common sight at Greggs are large queues at busy day parts, so work at improving speed of service is critical, in our view, for asset turn, when we consider speed of service at other operators (for example touch screen ordering at McDonalds, app based ordering at Wetherspoon). In light of the Q4 performance, the company now expects PBT to be “at least £88m” for FY18. This is slightly ahead of previous guidance given at the unscheduled profit upgrade in November, where guidance was PBT of at least £86m. Barclays’ forecasts are £86.5m for FY18 and £91m for FY19. There is no updated guidance for FY19, but the company is clearly confident, and comment they “enter the new year with good sales momentum and operational execution”. We remain big fans of the Greggs consumer offer (value for money, broad appeal), and performance has exceeded our expectations. The elevated PE rating, and relatively low FCF yield (due to capital intensity) are the main factors that inform our EW rating. Valuation: Dec-19 PE 19.5x, EV/EBITDA 8.8x, FCF yield 3.6% after all capex, and dividend yield 2.6%.

Viking1 Ref Greggs, look at the value the private equity boys are applying to Ole & Steen( bakery )
A. M. (@FATDAZ: signalling of some sort?)
BE11:20am

And Peel Hunt.

FATDAZ @viking i think its been conclusively provided by recent failures that venture cap backed eateries loaded with debt cant succeed
BE11:20am

Greggs updated the market last month with a surprisingly strong LFL showing and that has accelerated into December. The good work on queue lengths has persisted and you have to be impressed by the way that the marketing team gets Greggs’ product to the forefront of our minds: who hasn’t had a discussion about the vegan sausage roll in the past few days?! It’s not just sales vanity here either, there’s another profit upgrade (PBT of £87m becomes £89m for this year, £89m becomes £93m next year). We can’t fail to be impressed but unfortunately we were too short term in our thinking when LFL slowed earlier in the year and sense that the shares have got away from us a bit: we think that 20x is a full valuation but we see little chance of Greggs disappointing

.................. on a very dull trading update.

BE11:25am

Completions a fraction ahead of expectations -- up 3% -- and selling prices flat.

BE11:25am

Outlook statement says nothing much.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Whilst it is clearly too early to give a definitive view on 2019 trading, we continue to see solid forward sales
indicators and start the year with a very strong order book. We are pleased that customers remain able to
access a wide range of mortgage products at competitive interest rates. Employment trends also remain at healthy levels and customers will be able to benefit from the Government’s Help to Buy scheme until 2023. However, we will continue to closely monitor market conditions for any potential impact on customer
confidence in light of the wider political and economic uncertainty.

BE11:26am

Consensus doesn't change. Why's this sufficient to trigger a sector rally? Dunno.

BE11:26am

Here's Cazenove.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

The statement
comments that [the group has] delivered a strong performance during the second half of 2018, with very good
sales rates supported by positive customer demand and a supportive lending environment. For the year as a
whole, the net private reservation rate was 0.80 homes per outlet per week, up 4% y/y after being flat y/y for
the period to mid-November (2017: 0.77). This looks to imply that sales rate growth y/y for the period since
we last heard from the group has been slightly stronger than for July-Nov when rates were up 8% y/y,
suggesting there was no weakening of demand into the end of the year, and fears that customer confidence
might have been impacted by increased political uncertainty look to be unfounded. The group ended the year
with an order book that was up 9.4% in value terms and 16% in volume terms y/y. While the statement
comments that growth was driven by affordable housing (as evidenced in the price mix), we take that
comment to mean that private volumes in the order book are similar to this time last year (and therefore
consistent with guidance for flat sales volumes y/y for 2019). As previously reported current site volume are
down y/y (256 vs. 278), due to delays in site opening and faster closings due to strong sales in H2.

Plato the Cook Dull may be reassuring in exciting times...

We do not expect significant changes to consensus on the back of this update. Group's healthy forward sold position will remain supportive for 2019 expectations going forward and outlook comments on forward indicators remain positive. Focus on the call is likely to be on the strength of the private order book, outlet growth and margin performance into 2019. Stock trades on a 2019e P/B of 1.34x and offers a D/Y of c.13%

chad_john Debenhams can't be far off
Pharma (oh, missed the like-for-like bit, so shop sales also terrible)
BE11:37am

Despite annualising the marked step-down in trading of Sep/Oct 2017, Q3 UK LFLs continued their rate of decline at -11.4% (H1 -11.1%). Online particularly struggled, with sales -16.3%. However, and in contrast to H1 (which saw gross margin fall by -320bp), the H2 LFL outcome was partly the result of a reduction in the level of discounting and stock clearance; we suspect that gross margin ran in positive territory (NSe +50-100bp) through some key weeks in the period. Although the -11.4% LFL through Q3 was behind our expectations, Mothercare’s overall UK performance is consistent with our FY forecast, boosted by the improved gross margin and the UK store closure programme running ahead of schedule. Meanwhile, the international business posted a modest improvement in cc retail sales trend at -1.1% (H1 -2.0%), with solid results in Russia and the Middle East offset by declines in smaller non-core markets.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Positive progress continues to be made with the transformation plan – the store closure programme is ahead of schedule with all closures to be completed by April 2019, the first season’s product buy with the outsourced provider (for AW’19) has been completed, as has the £14.5m sale and leaseback of the UK head office. In particular, we see the outsourced buying as an opportunity for the group to begin reversing the many years of gross margin declines.

red a lot of the time the boards interests arent necessarily aligned with shareholders...
BE11:38am

We adjust the shape of our FY19 P&L today to reflect the
Q3 dynamics, including a reduction in revenue, an increase in gross margin, and lower costs. Overall, we leave our FY19 PBT estimate unchanged today, consistent with guidance in the statement that full year profit guidance is unchanged. While cognisant of the challenging UK trading conditions, we are encouraged by another period of forecast stability and recognise that clear strategic progress is being made towards Mothercare becoming a leaner, right-sized operation.

chad_john "outsourced buying" makes me shudder, as a former Retail buyer

FATDAZ @Chad a friend has made several batches of home brew that closely resemble ales made by leading brewers with the addition of different hops and selected ingredients such as orange peel all done with standar home brew kits and little trail and error with ingredients and little effort thereafter. the cost to him around 60p per print

11:39 am
BE11:39am

[T]here may be more to Mothercare than meets the eye, noting that we were already forecasting minus 12.5% H2
FY2019 LFL sales. International sales are stabilising, flat in its core five markets, whilst excellent work has been undertaken by Clive Whiley and Glyn Hughes, in particular, with the financial re-engineering of the business, (liquidity and portfolio restructuring), which provides resources and time to now focus upon the day job. New organisational structures should also inject more focus and accountability into the business, which we welcome. At the end of the day, Mothercare’s trading has to improve to harvest the benefits of the difficult re-structuring work undertaken to date. However, the upside potential could be considerable, leading us on balance to reiterate our HOLD stance but highlight that this troubled retail soul maybe in a much better place.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Here's Jefferies.

BE11:45am

Given that 57.5% of the ASDA consideration payable by SBRY to WMT is in the form of new SBRY shares, the incentive for the group to defend its profit delivery (and by extension its stand-alone equity value) is greater than usual. This motivation, and the flexibility warranted by a bonus line which we assume to be in the £100m region, may explain the disconnect between a deteriorating LFL momentum (-1.1% followed +0.6% in H1) and mgmt not explicitly flagging any issues with 18/19 estimates. We stay on PBT of £618m vs cons of £634m, as we assume a flattish Q4 LFL and H2 margin -27bps YoY (was +23bps in H1). We have been asked today whether we feel pressure on SBRY's equity could be a source of concern for the merger. We doubt it, as we believe an unlikely severe compression in SBRY's stand alone value would be needed to significantly impact the economics of the deal for WMT (note SBRY's share price averaged c.250p in the six months prior to the announcement).

FATDAZ @BE I liked the SBRY add though it was a rip off of JL's tone of voice in truth
BE11:45am

Under normal circumstances today's update would trigger a severe de-rating. But we are less than two months away from a CMA ruling that could lead to a 30%+ earnings accretive merger. With this in mind, and the equity pricing in a c.60% chance of the deal being blocked, a wait and see approach remains the best course of action. The CMA timetable remains for early Phase 2 findings by early Feb and final report by 5 March.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

60% looks about right. As one of the analysts noted last week, Sainsbury's entire pitch is that it needs the Asda merger to avoid having to go toe-to-toe with the discounters.

BE11:47am

But in what sense does that benefit the consumer?

undefined

The statement says very little:

BE11:48am

Since our last update on 28 November 2018, trading has continued to be strong. As we approach the end of our first half, we are now materially ahead of where we expected to be at this stage of the year.

Finlay @red true doesn't change the overall story. I'm just idly wondering if consumers defied expectations, one last hurrah and all that. By tomorrow, when M&S's reports that aside from specially sourced parsnip sales, Christmas was a shocker, the xmas apocalypse headlines will be back.
Mr Ticker Thanks - I suppose we will leave it to our imagination what 'materially' might mean!
hornblower both Mothercare notes from house brokers, can't really be negative after pushing the rights deal 6 months ago
BE11:49am

Which is nice, but what does it mean? Perhaps not a lot. Here's Credit Suisse.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

There is very limited colour in the brief statement, but to
be materially ahead of expectations after the first 5 months implies strong trading must be continuing to be broad based across all dimensions of Softcat's business. January is one of the seasonally strongest trading months of 1H and comps harden in 2H. Consequently, we think it is right to remain prudent. However, the positive tone to the statement leads us to upgrade FY19 and 20 EPS by 5% and 4% respectively.

FATDAZ early bath bye all
BE11:50am

Momentum continues to be very strong at Softcat and continued investment into the future lays an encouraging platform for further progress. However, the limited recurring revenue makes it hard to factor in the full extent of current momentum into FY forecasts. We continue to believe given superior growth, Softcat should trade in-line with high growth peers in the sector. That said, a sector derating now means blue chips like Accenture now trade on c20x vs 21x when we last updated our forecasts. This de-rating largely offsets the profit upgrade, leading to a modest change in TP from 660p to 664p. The obvious risk to our TP and rating is a sharp downturn in the UK economy which could impact discretionary spending.

red @hornblowerwith these things you need to stay away until there is a turnaround that is sustainable. anything else is really just hoping for the best without merit.
Excel Developer bye Daz
BE11:51am

Ditto Investec.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

We upgrade FY19E EPS by 5%, reflecting the
H119 strength, but do not extrapolate for H219 now; instead we wait for the H119 results for more details considering the backdrop (e.g. Brexit) and lack of future visibility in the model.

Pharma On supermarkets, has anyone noticed how they are now selling custom pack sizes for many branded goods, to stymie internet comparisons? Even the £5 Quality Street tubs they all sold come in a range of slightly different weights.Try searching for dishwasher tablets on mysupermarket, and many of the hits are unique to the supermarket you are search on (e.g. 28/30/32 tabs per pack).
BE11:51am

We retain our Hold based on valuation and shift our target price methodology to a headline cash-adjusted PE from a dividend (normal plus special) basis to reflect the more uncertain current stock market backdrop where headline PE ratios are generally the driving valuation barometer. Our target price is based on a 20x FY19E PE valuation to reflect the growth and near-term forecast underpin. With c.40p of cash per share, this equates to a 670p TP. This would equate to a dividend yield (normal plus special) of c 4.3%.

Excel Developer @Pharma: I compare on price per 100g
BE11:52am

Softcat barely trades quarter of a million a day, so it doesn't take much.

Pharma @BE interesting - and great neologism!

Okay, what else we got? GSK? Sure.

GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK:LSE): Last: 1,549, up 29.76 (+1.96%), High: 1,551, Low: 1,528, Volume: 2.00m
11:56 am
BE11:57am

Roche, UCB, GSK, Philips, Hikma and Sanofi were all at the JPM healthcare thing yesterday to say, "hey, we have cancer drugs too".

BE11:58am

Which is on the back of people seeing the Loxo bid and the Celgene bid and grouping them together (entirely wrongly, I'd suggest, because one's pipeline potential and the other's a distressed sale due to a patent cliff).

BE11:59am

Here's JPM's summary of what GSK said.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Tesaro acquisition: Company are bullish on PRIMA data showing a benefit in HRD+ve Ovarian cancer
in H2’19, with potential for success in the even broader HRD-ve population. For PARP inhibitor Zejula,
with relation to the H2’19 PRIMA study results, GSK were bullish on the prospects for showing a statistically
significant benefit beyond the BRCAm patients, in patients with HRD+ve status, based on the NOVO and
QUADRA study results. In addition, the company saw the potential for even broader success, in patients
categorised as HRD-ve, many of whom may actually have DDR mutations not detected by current HRD
positivity tests, which were originally designed to detect platinum sensitivity. Should PRIMA succeed, GSK
see this as a more attractive regimen than that used in Astra’s PAOLA study (also H2’19) which combines
their PARP with Avastin, with the associated administration and tolerability issues. GSK may develop their
own HRD diagnostic, which could be used for future trials, in order to detect a broader range of sensitising
mutations which could benefit from Lynparza therapy. GSK were also enthusiastic on the prospects for Zejula
for the treatment of lung cancer, both as a monotherapy, and potentially as a combination therapy with
Tesaro’s PD-1 (TSR-042). GSK also noted the plan to complete the US filing of the PD-1 as a monotherapy,
in 2nd-line endometrial cancer by the end of 2019. Though the PD-1 wasn’t the key target in the Tesaro
acquisition, the company see the asset offering some differentiation on the basis of dose frequency (every 6
weeks) and the higher dosing vs. other PD-1/PD-L1s, and the company noted the scale of the IO opportunity.

BE11:59am

HIF inhibitors, GSK believe their daprodustat program is better powered than Astra’s roxadustat
program, and hence could succeed, even if roxadustat were to fail to show a significant MACE benefit.
GSK noted the differences in trial designs between their daprodustat HIFI program (data 2020), and
Fibrogen/Astra’s roxadustat program (key safety data Q2’19). GSK believe their program is better powered,
with the ability to show a statistically significantly cleaner MACE profile for each individual study, vs.
Astra’s program only appearing to being powered to show a statistically significant benefit using all of their
dialysis studies pooled together. GSK also noted that it could be advantageous reporting their studies later
than Astra, as they would still have time to make powering, or other changes, if needed. Should roxadustat fail
to demonstrate a significant benefit, daprodustat could still go on to demonstrate a significant benefit, however
if roxadustat works, daprodustat is also very likely to work in terms of demonstrating a significantly cleaner
cardiovascular profile. If the HIFI class does succeed in showing a significantly cleaner MACE profile than
ESAs, GSK do not expect the class to be included in the bundle. Elsewhere at the conference, we heard FMC
note a preference for an HIFI offering every other day dosing (which would synchronise with dialysis
frequency), though GSK didn’t see this as an important differentiator (daprodustat is daily, roxadustat every
other day), noting the numerous daily oral therapies that dialysis patients already take.

BE11:59am

GSK’s pipeline has been streamlined, significant progress in immuno-oncology. GSK has now terminated
or divested 80 programs since EW assumed the CEO position. The company has made significant immuneoncology
pipeline progress in the last few months, with 7 more assets in the clinic since July 2018. In
particular, the company called out studies with the ICOS inhibitor, combined with Keytruda.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Which is a bit Inside Baseball, perhaps, but what do you expect.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 137.70, up 6.3 (+4.79%), High: 138.15, Low: 132.95, Volume: 6.05m
BE12:06pm

As flagged yesterday. Liberum shows its working:

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

We think ITV was paid 35-40p per month per subscriber under its previous retransmission deals with Virgin Media and (the still existing deal) Sky. This compared to an estimated £1-1.50 range for the likes of Discovery and Sky One. We think last year's ITV-Virgin Media deal put ITV up towards the top end of that £1-1.50 range so an extra £1 per month per sub. With roughly 3m Virgin Media cable TV subs in the ITV Plc area, this equated to our £35-40m uplift estimate (3m subs x £1 extra per month x 12 months).

BE12:07pm

ITV never gave financial details but STV suggested a £2m profit uplift by its deal with Virgin by 2021E. There are 4.2m cable subs in the UK and Ireland, so we think just under 4m for the UK. Scotland has the same level of cable penetration as the UK and STV covers 7% of total UK households. That would suggest a 60p uplift from STV’s deal. However, STV does not have ITV2/3/4, which have performed well (particularly ITV2 with Love Island). So we think ITV’s deal would have been closer to £1 extra as ITV would have had (1) an implicit ITV1 payment (as STV would have) (2) the uplift for its ITV2/3/4 channels and (3) the greater reach of its VOD services etc.

For Sky, we estimate there are roughly 10m Sky subs in the ITV Plc coverage network so 10m subs x £1 extra per month x 12 months = £120m annualised uplift.

BE12:07pm

Ian Whittaker also ponders why on earth ITV doesn't just buy STV, and concludes that it probably should.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

The case against a purchase has always been more political, namely would London-based ITV be allowed (in a political sense) to buy Scotland’s main broadcaster. We think those concerns are overdone. ITV could offer plenty of incentives to overcome opposition, the main one being to move a significant chunk of production up to Scotland to enhance Scotland as a creative job, plus offers not to make significant job cuts and keep a presence in Scotland.
